p: Independently of the input data type – static, azimuthal sample rotations, different detector positions (including merged/stitched images) – several data evaluation routines, e.g. cuts and integrations along specific reciprocal-space directions, crystal phase analysis, intensity corrections, fitting of peak positions, transformation to powder-like patterns etc., are available. Moreover, GIDVis can easily be used directly during measurements, e.g. to support sample alignment by extraction of height scans and rocking curves from two-dimensional intensity data, which can be directly evaluated further for the correct sample position, similar to what is done with a point detector. Because of the real-time data conversion to reciprocal space, GIDVis can also be used to monitor the measurement results, e.g. to make decisions on the optimum incident angle.
